segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 I'm Paul Coggin. I'm from Huntsville, Alabama in the U.S. And so this
presentation we're going to dive into a broad set of topics related to
space and cybersecurity. When you start talking about space, one of the key
components is the ground systems. Think of a ground system as the kind of like
your NOC or your SOC in your enterprise network where you manage your
enterprise network infrastructure. Similar with space systems, they
have ground stations that will be spread out across the world so that you have
visibility no matter where your assets are in orbit. You have visibility and you
can communicate with your assets and you can download information from the
from the payload as well as be able to send commands to the payload and to the
spacecraft itself. And in this example we're showing a ground station network
for NASA. But other other space systems constellations will have a ground
station network similar to this. But the big trend, everyone's talking about a
public cloud these days. Well also with space, space is utilizing the public
cloud. There's a leaf space out of Italy. Kubos who's got a application called
Major Tom that is hosted in Amazon AWS. Amazon is offering space ground station
services in the cloud where you can outsource the ground station to Amazon
where they have the antenna spread across geographic locations, their data
centers, so that you don't have to go build a large ground station network and
you can just outsource to them. Microsoft Azure has their orbit
service as well. And my understanding is Google is doing similarly for SpaceX
Starlink's project. So space is moving to the cloud. And also similarly it's not
real surprising that space providers are using infrastructure in the public
cloud. But what really surprised me is I started digging into space technologies
is that space is actually moving, that the cloud is actually moving to space in
some cases where vendors such as Leo cloud, new startups like Leo cloud are
actually going to put cloud infrastructure on their satellites in
space so that the say the image processing that is happening in space
where there's all kinds of imaging and data being gathered can be pre-processed
in space and then sent back down to earth as needed instead of having to
send everything. They're going to have data center capabilities in space to
provide all kinds of different services which is going to generate a lot of
interesting scenarios and questions for the cybersecurity industry with all
those assets going up into space. Something I was gonna make you aware of, a big
problem with with space is there is radiation and I'm going to go deeper
into this. And so there's companies that are coming out with new technologies to
support the data centers moving to space with like Roman out of Israel who's
created like a terabyte hard drive that's hardened for the harsh environment
of space. So this is that this is this market is really developing quickly to
support this. And what really got my attention here recently as I was
preparing this presentation is they're also now there's a startup is looking at
actually putting data centers on the moon in lava tunnels possibly on the
moon. So that's good so so the cloud is definitely moving to space quickly. And
there's one more example of NTT by a telecommunications company out of Japan
and they're they're planning on building a constellation and the
different satellites will have storage capabilities similar to your data center
on on earth. But they're gonna have that on their satellites and then they're
going to be interconnected there's gonna be a large network interconnected with
lasers free space optics. So it's gonna be a large network just like what we
have here on the ground but it's all going to be up in space. So this quick
this market is quickly evolving and then it goes like I said it's going to bring
in a lot of new questions about cybersecurity. You know how are we going
to deal with incident response, forensics, recovery, denial of service, lots of
different scenarios as all of those networks that we're used to being having
on the ground or moving up up to space. Now we're getting to space depending on
the application it could be running the satellites like one web the SpaceX star
link those those satellites are typically running at Leo in low-earth
orbit. Now your cable TV and a lot of your telecommunications satellites
they're typically in geo where in Leo those satellites are in low-earth orbit
they're they're revolving around the earth around about every four hours
they're they're making a an orbit around the earth with geo those satellites are
fixed and they're they're pinpointed they're pointed to follow the earth's
rotation so they're always pointing at the same place on the earth with your
geo so that's that we're very familiar with for telecommunications but what
you're hearing about in the news so much lately is with one web and SpaceX etc as
the Leo orbits. Now from a threat standpoint from a cybersecurity and just
physical kinetic threats the the American scientists the Federation of
American scientists have defined like five major categories of threats to
space you have deception where you know someone's going to mess with you think
about like spoofing GPS there's a lot of information out there now in the news
about AIS information that the ships use to know their location GPS GNSS here in
Europe being spoofed temporary disruption may be like electronic
warfare where someone turns on a radio frequency jammer where the signal is
jammed temporarily as soon as the power is removed the signal is restored that
would you know some disruption or it could be that there's a denial a service
where someone's goes and saturates the link somehow and in a degradation could
be they maybe they're using a laser or something to that's actually damaged the
satellite in you know or complete destruction because there's been a lot
of that in the news lately like a missile test against the satellite to
blow the satellite up and then creates a debris field which creates the concern
of what we call Kessler syndrome where there could be a chain reaction of
debris hitting debris or other space assets and it causes the chain reaction
to work to the point that space is no longer usable because of the debris
field in some of the threads some of them are reversible like I've mentioned
the electronic warfare you turn on the signal you turn on the jammer it and it
affects the system you remove the power and it'll go away all the way to two
threads like a missile hitting a rocket and blowing it up and in that case it
would be non-reversible and then with cyber it could be reversible or
non-reversible depending on the type of attack but but speaking of the
non-reversible just wanted to as I was researching this I wanted to bring this
out of some examples of some kinetic attacks back in the 70s I thought it was
interesting to learn that in the 70s that one of the space station Alma that
the Soviet Union had actually had a machine gun on it a cannon 23 millimeter
cannon I thought that was really interested and there's there's talk

a lot we have a lot of examples of this a lot of a lot of the satellite
communications are not encrypted though we assume it's encrypted it's not in
many many cases it's not I'm going to give a lot of examples it's a from a

state could be military could be Intel they're going to have you know a lot

there wasn't but but it could cause all kinds of disruptions all this these

term did a Einstein denial of service because that's what E equal MC square
his equation he's so famous for is defined for is to define the energy of
the mass in the speed which is the speed of light square of the particles that
are heading out into the solar system sourced from the Sun now this these

through space that's reason that a lot of the spacecraft are not using

designers the manufacturers of the spacecraft would have to go use
radiation hardened equipment they would have to spend a lot more money hardening
that equipment to survive the hostile environment of space and the last thing
you want to do is put a satellite in space or spacecraft in space you didn't
spend the money up front to get it hardened against the radiation and all
the particles that are against sent through the the galaxy through space and
and have disruptions of your encryption because what happens there's a specifically
the ion charges it could go when it hits those elect hits the electronics on
spacecraft it can only it could just take one particle and it calls was what
they call it a single event upset and it'll flip a bit in the electronics and
if you're doing encryption it'll mess up all that King and then you're gonna
lose your connection and you're going you're gonna lose your contact with the
the payload as well as you're gonna lose your control of the spacecraft and so
you got to go and wait for that that it for that system to reestablish resync
the encryption so that you can log back into your system again so that's the
reason a lot of the spacecraft if they don't go through the expense if they
don't go through the expense of getting the radiation hardening they're gonna
they're not going to use encryption because they'll lose they'll lose
control of their satellite and so here's an example here's an example of a

another famous example is proving the point that a lot of the satellite
